page.title: 03RHUM EXCAVATION_FINDINGS
page.content: C14 determinations obtained from burnt hazelnut shells in one of the pits showed that the earliest human activity on the site was infact some of the earliest evidence of people anywhere in Scotland. As the climate improved at the end of the last Ice Age, 8500 years ago, people were already visiting Rhum to make camp for at least part of every year. These people did not farm the land, the island would have provided plenty of food: animals, birds, fish, shellfish, plants, nuts and berries. They visited Guirdil on the west coast to collect Rhum Bloodstone which was flaked and shaped to provide sharp edges for cutting, arrowheads for hunting, and many other tools. They did not use metals but there has been found much waste from making stone tools as well as debris from using/resharpening them
